Symrise, Inc.
                                                               BUSHY PARK SITE
                                                               GOOSE CREEK, SC
                                                               June 16, 2004

I. FACILITY INFORMATION

Symrise, Inc. at Bushy Park, SC,  produces aroma chemicals and cosmetic ingredients.  The Symrise corporate headquarters is located In Holtzminden, Germany. ( Symrise GmbH & Co., KG, MÃ¼hlenfeldstrasse 1,D-37603, Holzminden, Germany)  The Symrise, Bushy Park Site manufactures various forms of menthol, sunscreens, cooling agents, and fragrance specialties.  Symrise, Bushy Park was formerly a subsidiary of Bayer Corporation who established the Bushy Park site in 1970.  Haarmann & Reimer (now Symrise)  was acquired by EQT Partners on October 1, 2002.  Prior to this date, H&R was included in the RMP considerations of Bayer Corporation who filed their RMP by the statutory deadline.  Bayer Corporation divested its Bushy Park holdings to Lanxess Corporation on 7/1/2004, who renamed the site to the Bushy Park Industrial Complex (BPIC) in 2006.

Symrise is located within the BPIC 1650 acre site which is operated as an Industrial Park wherein Lanxess owns the land and the various tenants own and operate the assets on the land.  The site is on the Cooper River just a few miles east of Goose Creek, S C. Symrise has contracted with Lanxess Corporation to purchase various materials and services.

II. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Symrise is committed to health, the environment and safety.  Symrise considers its responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and the area communities of primary importance in the conduct of its business.  It is Symrise's policy to comply with all applicable laws and regulations and to establish and implement responsible practices where law

s and regulations do not exist.  Further, Symrise will work with government and industry groups to foster the development of appropriate health, environment and safety programs, laws and regulations.  Symrise will communicate with its employees, customers, suppliers, communities and the public to recognize and respond to their concerns and to improve their understanding of the health, environment and safety considerations related to Symrises's operations and products.  Symrise is committed to continually improving health, environment and safety performance.

Our industry creates products and services that make life better for many people around the world - both today and tomorrow.  We will make continuous progress toward the goal of no accidents, injuries or harm to the environment.  We will adhere to the following principals:

+ To provide chemicals that can be manufactured, transported, used and disposed of safely.
+ To make health, safety, the environment and resource conservation critical considerations for all new and existing products and processes.
+ To provide information on health or environmental risks and pursue protective measures for employees, the public and other key stakeholders.
+ To work with customers, carriers, suppliers, distributors and contractors to foster the safe use, transport and disposal of chemicals.
+ To operate our facilities in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public.
+ To support education and research on the health, safety and environmental effects of our products and processes.
+ To work with others to resolve problems created by past handling and disposal practices.

Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

Symrise has worked with the county and local agencies and response groups to provide information about the chemicals we use on our site.  In addition, the site emergency plans have been integrated with the emergency plans of the county and local fire departments.  Symr

ise has participated in disaster drills held by the LEPC.

Compliance and Commitment to Safety

Protection of our employees and neighbors is our highest priority, and that is why we have installed multiple safeguards to ensure that all chemicals are handled safely.  We also work closely with our suppliers, other companies, local officials and the public to maintain stringent safety and environmental programs and to minimize risks.  

In keeping with our commitment, Symrise has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in compliance with guidelines established by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Under EPA guidelines, facilities that handle certain quantities of regulated chemicals must submit plans that show the consequences of hypothetical chemical releases.  Facilities must also outline their measures to reduce the risk of releases and minimize their effects.

Several processes at the site are regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements listed in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  PSM and RMP complement each other in that PSM is concerned about the employee and RMP is concerned about the public and the environment.  The Bushy Park site is in full compliance with the PSM requirements.  

III. RMP REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Final construction and start up has been completed on the new process subsequent to our initial RMP submission in November 2002. The new process is in compliance with PSM requirements for the Risk Management Program listed in 40 CFR Part 68.  The new process includes an ammonia refrigeration system and a pentane storage and handling system.  Ammonia is present as liquefied gas under pressure.  It is regulated as a toxic substance.  Pentane is a liquid stored at ambient temperature and is regulated as a flammable material. 

Symrise uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in the process area. Prior to the initial submission, Symrise (formerly H&R) was included in the Bayer RMP for ammonia.  It is delivered via an overhead pipelin

e system from Lanxess Corporation's plant-wide distribution system.  Ammonia is a colorless gas with a strong pungent odor.  Exposure to ammonia can irritate the eyes, nose and throat.  Exposure to extremely high levels can result in a buildup of fluid in the lungs and can be life threatening.

Symrise uses pentane in the CHDD process area as a solvent in the manufacturing of a fragrance product.  Pentane is a highly flammable liquid that can reach explosive concentrations in the atmosphere if released without restriction.

IV. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the past five years Symrise has not experienced any release of ammonia or pentane that requires listing in the RMP information we are submitting.  

V. EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Incident and Emergency Guidelines

Symrise has multiple safeguards in place to ensure safe handling of ammonia and pentane and to prevent releases of these substances.  Our facility is prepared to handle emergencies such as hurricanes and tornadoes as well as chemical releases.  In the unlikely event a release occurs, we work to contain the release quickly and to minimize its impact on plant personnel and neighbors.  If a release occurs equipment that supplies the regulated substance would be shut down quickly by remote control.

Symrise is a partner in the Bushy Park Industrial Complex.  Lanxess manages the Industrial Complex Emergency Operations Center (EOC) that Symrise participates in.  If a release occurs, the EOC is activated and the follow actions are implemented:
+ The plant alarm would be sounded and the emergency communicated to plant personnel over the emergency alert system.
+ Trained on-site emergency response teams would be activated and take prompt action to control and stop the release. 
+ Emergency response personnel would evaluate the extent and impact of the release
+ If the release would have potential off-site impact, or outside assistance needed, local and county emergency response personnel would be notified and acti

vated.
+ Neighbors in the immediate area that might be affected would be notified and advised to take appropriate action.
+ If necessary, Site specialists would be activated to perform computer modeling to estimate the area affected by the release. 
+ If needed, the site has immediate access to emergency resources and assistance from its corporate headquarters.

Training and Preparation

Symrise trains employees on the safe handling of ammonia and pentane and how to respond appropriately, should a release occur.  Some examples of our preparation and training include:
+ Written procedures to handle all types of emergencies.
+ Regularly scheduled safety training for operators and maintenance personnel responsible for the regulated substance system.

Symrise is a partner in the Bushy Park Industrial Complex.  Lanxess manages various overall Industrial Complex Emergency Services that Symrise participates in.  These services include the following:
+ Trained and experienced on-site emergency response teams ( Fire & Rescue, EMT's, and Hazmat ).
+ Emergency planning with the local fire department and county emergency preparedness personnel.
+ Planning and training with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and participation in annual drills.
+ Routine testing of plant emergency response, alerting, and communications systems.
+ Fully equipped emergency response vehicles (fire truck, ambulance, and hazmat truck).
+ Emergency response personnel trained annually at nationally recognized schools.
+ Certified Hazmat Team to respond to off-site transportation and distribution incidents.

VI. RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL - SPECIFIC PREVENTION 

Assuring Safe Operations

Symrise has established programs and activities to ensure safe operation of its ammonia, and pentane handling systems.  Some examples include:
+ Production and maintenance personnel are trained in the safe operation and repair of the system.
+ Written operating and maintenance procedures are in place and

updated regularly.
+ Full in-depth hazard and operability studies are conducted by qualified personnel at least every 5 years.
+ Complete safety reviews are conducted prior to making any changes to the operation or equipment.
+ Health, environmental, and safety audits are conducted at least every 3 years to ensure compliance with regulations.
+ Maintenance work is planned ahead of time and work permits issued to assure work is performed safely.
+ Regular inspections of equipment, instruments, and piping are conducted to assure integrity of the system.
+ Scheduled preventive maintenance work is performed to assure equipment is safe, reliable, and efficient.
+ All incidents are investigated and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.

Designing for Safety

Symrise has installed multiple safeguards and systems to reduce the likelihood of ammonia, and pentane incidents, including:
+ Piping systems where applicable are all welded construction outside of containment areas.
+ The systems are equipped with instrumentation that controls each operation within safe limits.
+ Emergency shutdown systems are installed to immediately isolate each system and minimize upsets.
+ Operating personnel monitor each system regularly to identify any potential problems.

VII. IMPROVING SAFETY PERFORMANCE

Symrise has an ongoing commitment to safety.  As proof of this there has only been five OSHA recordable injuries at Symrise's Busy Park Plant since January 1996.  Symrise uses a structured approach to safety management that relies strongly on the participation of all employees and insures communication of safety related information at all levels of the plant.  In addition Symrise's Continuous Improvement and Total Production Maintenance Programs and ISO-9001 process include safety performance and improvement on an equal basis with quality and productivity.

Symrise management encourages all of the Continuous Improvement and TPM teams to review and evaluate operations and recommend safety,

environmental, and operational improvements.  This philosophy applies to our entire facility.  Past efforts in all areas of the plant have resulted in projects like:
1. Redesign of an organic/water separator tank that improved product and raw material recovery from the wastewater stream and lowered BOD loading in wastewater influent to the treatment plant.
2. Redesign of the battery changing and charging building for safer handling of large electric fork truck batteries.  The redesign included improved spill prevention and containment features to better prevent spills of the battery acid.
3. A three-phase review and upgrade of the ladders, platforms and handrails associated with our chemical storage tanks to improve safety conditions and provide a safer work environment for our employees.
4. The relocation and installation of our truck unloading station with improved safety features, including guarded platforms and mechanical gangways, providing safe access to the top of the truck for the purpose of sample extraction.  In addition, the new truck unloading facility is designed with improved spill containment and material recovery features.
5. The reconditioning and sealing of our tank farm containment areas as a proactive measure in avoiding potential soil and ground water and storm water contamination.
